title.narrative: LaunchPAD for a Climate Model Evaluation Hub for Africa - Future Climate for Africa (FCFA) Accountable Grant

description.narrative: SouthSouthNorth, as the holder of the Accountable Grant, oversees the management the LaunchPAD. Oxford University is the lead implementing partner, contracting individuals from other institutions to work on the project. Due to the qualitative nature of this activity, all reporting is done through the submission of quarterly reports, rather than using IATI's quantitative submissions. This activity is referred to under Output 1 in the reporting.

The Future Climate for Africa (FCFA) programme has made substantial progress in understanding the African climate and has developed methodologies to evaluate the regional climate processes and impact-relevant indices which matter locally. As part of the FCFA Accountable Grant funded by the UK Government's Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office (FCDO), previously referred to as the Department for International Development (DfID) (IATI identifier GB-1-203835-107), the LaunchPAD project was initiated as one of the three key outputs to continue the legacy of the broader FCFA programme (IATI identifier GB-1-203835-102). The LaunchPAD is the first phase of the Climate Model Evaluation Hub for Africa and has been established to build upon the novel science findings and methods to extend the work to more regions and systems, and to embed tools into automated software that will fast-track the understanding of how well climate models simulate climate dynamics in African regions. The establishment of the Hub was made possible by building on existing FCFA research networks through researchers at the University of Oxford, University of Yaounde I, University of Nairobi, University of Cape Town, Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology, and the Met Office, showcasing the strong legacy and importance of FCFA partnerships between British and African research institutions.

activity-date.narrative: The LaunchPAD end date was initially August 2020. Due to COVID-19 travel restrictions, secondments for the research fellows were unable to commence. Therefore, SSN are in discussions with DfID regarding the length of the necessary costed extension, which is planned for the end of January 2021. The formal extension with Oxford or DfID have not yet been finalised.
The contract with Oxford University was signed in June 2019 to initiate the implementation of the LaunchPad.

transaction.ref: Disbursement to University of Oxford: Quarter 2 (June, July & August 2019)

description.narrative: On grant of funds from SSN to the University of Oxford

provider-org.narrative: SouthSouthNorth (SSN) disbursed funds to the University of Oxford

receiver-org.narrative: University of Oxford receives funds to implement the activities of the FCFA model evaluation hub.

description.narrative: Oxford University is contracted to host the first phase of the Climate Model Evaluation Hub for Africa, and initiate a short-term programme of work in collaboration with the Met Office and several African universities. The following activities will constitute the core functions of the hub: • Support for African Early Career Researchers: a 12-month fellowship programme for research students or postdocs, including funding for research time (to engage in analysis of climate models over Africa), and travel funding for engagement with modelling centres and international scientists, including a research visit to a UK research institution of up to a month. • Collaboration between scientists and programmers to develop automated evaluation software: at least one scientific programmer contracted to work with scientists to develop their evaluation tools to the stage where these can be integrated into automated evaluation software, potentially through Met Office Auto Assess, ESMValTool, and the CMIP DECK facility. • Workshops to lay the groundwork for collaboration: a Phase 1 workshop will be held for all participating scientists and technicians, to review existing results and plans and consider the usefulness of different model analyses for decision makers working on resilience. Near the end of the first phase, a second workshop will be hosted to engage the wider African climate science community and other modellers, and plan the next phase of the model evaluation hub.

provider-org.narrative: SouthSouthNorth initiated a contract with the Oxford University to implement the LaunchPAD.

receiver-org.narrative: Oxford University is contracted to implement the LaunchPAD.

title.narrative: Quarter 1 Report (March, April & May 2019) - FCFA Accountable Grant

description.narrative: Reporting is completed quarterly using the DfID template. Reporting is primarily qualitative and progress is measured against the FCFA Accountable Grant logframe. All IATI reporting is done through the submission of the quarterly report documents. In the quarterly report, all progress defined as Output 1 is relevant to this activity.
